importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: China expanded export controls on 12 out of 17 rare-earth metals and certain refining equipment, effective December 1, as a response to US trade restrictions.
Donald Trump announced a 100% tariff on Chinese goods, effective from November 1, and accused China of 'trade hostility', threatening to scrap the planned meeting with Xi Jinping.
Trump and Xi are expected to meet in South Korea during the APEC summit, though the trade dispute has created uncertainty about the meeting’s occurrence.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from late 2023 to mid-2024 saw a series of US export controls and restrictions on semiconductors and technology, including Biden's actions limiting access to advanced chips and AI technologies for China.
Following a tit-for-tat tariff escalation, the US and China agreed to a 90-day truce in August 2024, which was extended twice, signaling a temporary pause in their trade conflict.

keyTakeAways: China accused the United States of 'double standards' after imposing export controls on rare earth metals in response to US restrictions on Chinese industries, including maritime and shipbuilding.
Donald Trump threatened to impose a 100% tariff on Chinese goods, effective from November 1, 2025, citing China’s export controls on rare earths as a trigger, raising fears of a renewed trade war.
China justifies its rare earth export controls as a national security measure, citing US trade curbs on Chinese entities and sectors linked to military and advanced technology.
The US has a history of imposing tariffs on Chinese goods, starting with a 10% tariff in 2024, rising to 34% and 145% in previous administrations, with China retaliating with equivalent tariffs.
The US and China have a long-standing pattern of reciprocal tariffs, with a significant drop in tariffs to 30% and 10% in May 2024, followed by a temporary truce and renewed tension in 2025.

US export controls on semiconductors and AI technologies, especially under the Biden administration, have targeted China’s access to advanced chips and manufacturing tools, particularly from Nvidia and in the semiconductor supply chain.
In 2020, the US restricted Huawei from using US tech globally, leading to a global tech supply chain realignment, with Huawei being blocked from selling in the US.
China’s rare earth exports are critical for global technology, including electric vehicles, smartphones, and weapons, giving Beijing significant leverage in trade negotiations.
Experts suggest that China’s tightening of rare earth controls is a 'pre-meeting choreography' aimed at gaining leverage during the upcoming Trump-Xi meeting in South Korea.
Both nations are seen as weaponizing economic interdependence, with no 'saints' in the game, as noted by analysts Manoj Kewalramani and Kristin Vekasi.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The article details the escalating trade conflict between the United States and China, centered on a 100% tariff threat by Donald Trump against Chinese goods in response to China’s export controls on rare earth metals. This action follows a history of reciprocal tariffs, starting from Trump’s 2018 policies and continuing under Biden with strict export controls on semiconductors and AI technologies. China justifies its rare earth restrictions as a national security measure, accusing the US of discriminatory trade practices and overreach. Experts interpret China’s measures as strategic 'pre-meeting choreography' to gain leverage ahead of a high-stakes meeting between Trump and Xi Jinping in South Korea. Analysts note that while the US holds more strategic tools and global influence, China is better prepared and more strategic in its policy responses, with both sides maintaining escalation tools to project strength. The situation adds significant uncertainty to global trade, highlighting how economic policies are increasingly intertwined with national security and geopolitical competition.
title: Trump’s 100% tariff threat: History of US trade measures against China
